prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the person who wrote this is in the wrong. The situation is about splitting bills with their girlfriend.

First, the author mentions that they pay all the rent and bills because their girlfriend only works part-time. They didn't mind until a recent incident where they asked her to pay for takeout because they forgot their wallet. The girlfriend reacted negatively, which upset the author. Now they're considering making her pay some bills going forward.

Hmm, so the key points here. The author is taking into account that the girlfriend's income is lower. But they're upset about her reaction to a small purchase. The author is feeling that even though it's a small amount, the principle of sharing expenses is important. They want her to start contributing more, even if it's just a little.

Is the author right to be upset? Well, in a relationship where both people live together, it's common to share expenses based on income. If the girlfriend works part-time, maybe she can contribute a small amount. The author might be right in wanting a more balanced approach. But the incident itself was a single takeout, which the author says was under $40. The girlfriend's reaction might have been out of frustration if she's used to not contributing, but the author is overreacting by making it about principle now.

On the other hand, the author's approach might be a bit harsh. They're letting a single incident affect their feelings about the situation. Maybe they should have had a conversation about splitting expenses earlier. By waiting until this incident, they're making it seem like the girlfriend suddenly needs to pay more, which could be unfair. Also, the author's tone when telling her to pay the takeout might have been confrontational, leading to her defensive reaction.

The question is whether the author is in the wrong. If the author is now holding this one incident against her and using it as a reason to make her pay more, that might not be fair. Relationships require communication and mutual understanding. Instead of making her start paying bills immediately, discussing expectations and splitting costs based on their respective incomes would be a better approach. The author might be right in wanting a fair system, but the way they're handling it could be wrong. So the answer might be A, the author is in the wrong because they're overreacting to a single incident and not considering the girlfriend's perspective and financial situation properly.
